overview: From 2025-09-01 to 2025-10-01, ethereum-optimism/docs had 16 new PRs (8 merged), 4 new issues, and 75 active contributors.

topIssues.title: [DOCS] (via Msilb) 'For Indexers & Data Providers' page/callout
topIssues.author: OPMattie
topIssues.body:
Via @MSilb7:

Idea:
Every single data-related tool in crypto (i.e. Dune, Google, open-source indexers) has not known that there are extra transaction receipt fields for OP (l1Fee, l1GasUsed, l1FeeScalar, l1GasPrice)
Should we have this called out in like a “for indexers & data providers” page or something similar? Idk if this would completely solve the problem, but at least it’s something to link to.
P.S. new docs are cool

## Description of the Documentation You'd Like
Explain what the final documentation page or pages should look like. Do you need a guide, tutorial, FAQ, troubleshooting page or more than one page? Do you have any source/content information to provide for the requested page(s)?

## Links to Related Pages
Provide links to any related content pages for this documentation request. This will help us to determine where the page(s) from your docs request should live  
(e.g. a new node operators resource will likely link to other pages in the node operators section of the docs).

## Additional Context
Provide any additional context about this documentation request. What problems did you run into that caused you to make this request? 
Which existing documentation pages did you already try as a solution to your problem? Why do you think the requested page(s) will be beneficial to developers in the Optimism Collective?

topIssues.title: [2024 Q4 Audit] [page-path]
topIssues.author: cshein45
topIssues.body:
## Description of the updates required

The current content on the page is outdated and does not reflect recent developments in the Movement Network. We need to update information related to the MOVE token utility, DAO governance structure, staking features, and community fundraising initiatives (e.g. Ko-fi, NFTs, grants).

Example page to update: [wiki.movement.xyz/kokyat](https://wiki.movement.xyz/kokyat)

## Acceptance Criteria

- Updated section for MOVE token staking with clear parameters and benefits
- Visual diagram for DAO governance structure
- Inclusion of current community funding models (Ko-fi, grants, NFT utility)
- Bilingual content support (English + Burmese)

## Resources

- [Movement Wiki](https://wiki.movement.xyz/kokyat)
- [Whitepaper](https://www.movementnetwork.xyz/whitepaper/movement-whitepaper_en.pdf)
- [GitHub](https://github.com/movementlabsxyz)
- [Notion Spec](https://www.notion.so/1ab2c82b8cb580ccb5bdcf7625f72c86)
- SMEs: KoKyat, ThaeThae, HanGyi

## Action items

1. Review linked resources and meet with SMEs (KoKyat, etc.)
2. Write the first draft of updated content
3. Share draft with SMEs for feedback
4. Conduct peer review (e.g. HanGyi or ThaeThae)
5. Final SME approval
6. Publish on wiki.movement.xyz

## Github Issue Label Criteria

<details>
<summary>Priority</summary>

- `p-high`: This is important for public-facing DAO and token communication.

</details>

<details>
<summary>T-shirt size</summary>

- `s-M`: Moderate work requiring cross-team collaboration and translation.

</details>

<details>
<summary>Content evaluation</summary>

- `a-moderate`: The page requires several updates and partial rewrites.

</details>

## MDX Metadata Format

```mdx
---
title: "Movement DAO Governance & Token Utility"
tags: ["movement-network", "dao", "tokenomics", "funding"]
description: "Learn how the Movement Network organizes DAO governance, token staking, and community fundraising via onchain tools."
---

<details>
<summary>Component tags</summary>


l1-contracts
l2-contracts
standard-bridge
op-gov-token
op-program
op-node
dev-console

</details>

<details>
<summary>Engineering tags</summary>

eng-growth
eng-devx
eng-protocol

</details>
```

topIssues.title: Movement
topIssues.author: cshein45
topIssues.body:
## Description  
This issue is to request updated or new documentation in support of Movement Network’s integration and use of Optimism infrastructure. Specifically, we would like to ensure the docs reflect:

- MOVE token utility (bridging, staking, governance)
- DAO setup and integration on Optimism
- Community contribution guidance (e.g. using Tally, Safe, Ko-fi)
- Optimism-native features leveraged by Movement Network

## Acceptance criteria  
- Relevant Optimism documentation updated to include Movement use case  
- Any Movement-specific pages or references are clearly documented  
- GitHub and Wiki links to Movement assets are included  
- Aligned with Optimism documentation structure and tone  
- Final review by Optimism Docs team

## User stories  
- As a builder using Movement on Optimism, I want to understand how to stake MOVE or vote in DAO proposals  
- As a governance participant, I want clarity on how Movement leverages Optimism infra like the OP stack or bridges  
- As a contributor, I want clear steps to get involved in the Movement DAO from an Optimism perspective

## Resources and support  
- Website: [https://movementlabs.xyz](https://movementlabs.xyz)  
- Wiki: [https://wiki.movement.xyz/kokyat](https://wiki.movement.xyz/kokyat)  
- GitHub: [https://github.com/movementlabsxyz](https://github.com/movementlabsxyz)  
- Token: 0x3073f7aAA4DB83f95e9FFf17424F71D4751a3073  
- Governance Tools: Tally, Safe, EAS  
- SME Contacts: KoKyat, ThaeThae, HanGyi

## Action items  
1. Review Movement-related tooling on Optimism  
2. Draft supporting docs or examples  
3. Link to Movement resources and update references in the docs  
4. Review with OP Labs Docs team  
5. Final approval and publish

<!-- Leave a comment (optional) -->
Looking forward to collaborating! Please let us know if there’s a preferred structure for partner project documentation.

topIssues.title: [2024 Q4 Audit] [page-path]
topIssues.author: killers10
topIssues.body:
<!-- this template is intended for internal OP Labs usage -->

## Description of the updates required

<!-- Write a description of the current state of the page. -->

### Acceptance criteria

<!-- Definition of done for the assignee -->

### Resources

<!-- Supporting docs, points of contact, and any additional helpful info -->

### Action items

<!-- The process for working through this issue for example:
1. Read through resources and meet with SME
2. Write the first draft
3. Share draft with SMEs and implement feedback
4. Peer review
5. Final SME review
6. Publish -->

## Github issue label criteria

> Choose the appropriate github issue labels for each page.

<details>

<summary>Priority</summary>

- `p-on-hold`: (Defer) Tasks that are currently not actionable due to various reasons like waiting for external inputs, dependencies, or resource constraints. These are reviewed periodically to decide if they can be moved to a more active status.
- `p-low`: (Nice to do) Tasks that have minimal impact on core operations and no immediate deadlines. These tasks are often more about quality of life improvements rather than essential needs.
- `p-medium`: (Could do) Tasks that need to be done but are less critical than high-priority tasks. These often improve processes or efficiency but can be postponed if necessary without immediate severe repercussions.
- `p-high`: (Should do) Important tasks that contribute significantly to long-term goals but may not have an immediate deadline. Delaying these tasks could have considerable negative effects but are not as immediate as critical tasks.
- `p-critical`: Tasks that have immediate deadlines or significant consequences if not completed on time. These are non-negotiable and often linked to core business functions or legal requirements. 
</details>

<details>

<summary>T-shirt size</summary>

- `s-XS`: (< 1 day) Very simple tasks that require minimal time and effort.
- `s-S`: (few days) Tasks that are straightforward but require a bit more time to complete.
- `s-M`: (1-2 weeks) Tasks that involve a moderate level of complexity and collaboration.
- `s-L`: (several weeks) Complex tasks that require significant time investment and coordination across multiple teams. 
- `s-XL`: (> 1 month) Very large and complex projects that involve extensive planning, execution, and testing. 
</details>

<details>

<summary>Content evaluation</summary>
- `a-delete`: don't need this page 
- `a-duplicate`: some content lives elsewhere 
- `a-minor`: needs small revisions 
- `a-moderate`: needs moderate revisions 
- `a-critical`: needs a lot of work
</details>

## MDX Metadata format

> We will be adding better metadata to the header of each page. 
> If I was actively searching for this page on google and this description was the search result, would I know it's the correct page?
> Parse the component and feature tags to add.

```mdx
---
title: "Your Title Here"
tags: ["tag1", "tag2"]
description: "A short description of the content."
---
```

<details>
<summary>Component tags</summary>

```
op-node
op-geth
op-reth
op-erigon
op-nethermind
batcher
standard-bridge
sequencer
l1-contracts
l2-contracts
precompiles
predeploys
preinstalls
op-proposer
op-challenger
op-gov-token
op-supervisor
op-conductor
fp-contracts
cannon
op-program
asterisk
kona
superchain-registry
supersim
dev-console
opsm
mcp
mcp-l2
deputy-guardian
liveness-guard
dispute-mon
op-beat
op-signer
monitorism
blockspace-charters
op-workbench
kubernetes-infrastructure
devops-tooling
artifacts-packaging
sequencer-in-a-box
devnets
performance-tooling
peer-management-service
proxyd
zdd-service
snapman
security-tools
superchain-ops
op-deployer
```
</details>

<details>
<summary>Engineering tags</summary>

```
eng-platforms
eng-growth
eng-devx
eng-protocol
eng-proofs
eng-evm
eng-security
```
</details>

topPRs.title: Update L2 rollup testnet tutorial
topPRs.author: krofax
topPRs.body:
<!--
Contributions welcome! See https://github.com/ethereum-optimism/.github/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md
-->

**Description**

This PR adds a complete, modernized tutorial for deploying an OP Stack testnet chain using the latest `op-deployer` workflow. The tutorial replaces outdated manual deployment approaches with current best practices and provides a step-by-step guide for setting up a full testnet chain.

topContributors.summary: geoknee: Focused on the "min-base-fee" feature, proposing changes to both implementation and design documentation. This work included opening a pull request to bring in op-geth code in `ethereum-optimism/optimism` (#17307) and another to update a calculation in the feature's design doc (#333). Alongside this development, they actively supported the team by providing 12 code reviews. Their commits primarily consisted of bug fixes and tests, spread across 47 modified files.

scharissis: Focused on improving infrastructure and the acceptance testing framework, landing a significant logging refactor in `ethereum-optimism/infra#453` and introducing `mise` for tool version management via `ethereum-optimism/infra#452`. They drove further testing improvements by creating and closing two issues (`infra#398`, `optimism#16272`) to streamline test execution and provided 7 code reviews. With ongoing work in `op-acceptance-tests` and `kurtosis-devnet`, their contributions were primarily centered on bug fixes and feature enhancements.

blmalone: Focused on improving CI performance and stability within the `ethereum-optimism/superchain-ops` repository. They delivered a notable performance improvement by optimizing account access decoding in CI (#1178) and reduced common CI failures by adjusting concurrent processes (#1177). Their work, primarily consisting of bug fixes, also included smaller corrections to versioning and nonce handling (#1183, #1176), with changes concentrated in documentation and configuration files.

smartcontracts: This month, smartcontracts focused on a significant body of work centered on bug fixes and new features, authoring 31 commits. This effort resulted in substantial changes across 167 files (+4676/-1739 lines), with a primary focus on bugfix work (68%). While no pull requests were merged, they participated in code review by providing comments on 4 pull requests.

JosepBove: Focused on the `superchain-ops` repository, preparing a significant change to enable and disable LivenessModule2 templates. This work is captured in an open pull request (#1179) which modifies 130 files with over 5,000 lines of code changes. Alongside this development effort, they also participated in code review by providing comments on 6 pull requests. Based on the file modifications, this work had a strong emphasis on testing.

bitwiseguy: This month, bitwiseguy focused on improving the project's build process, opening a pull request to enhance the build recipe for op-deployer (ethereum-optimism/optimism#17304). In addition to this work, they contributed collaboratively by reviewing and approving one pull request and commenting on an issue. Their code changes were entirely focused on this tooling enhancement.

pcw109550: This month, pcw109550 focused on improving the testing capabilities within the `ethereum-optimism/optimism` repository. Their main contribution was adding sync namespace support to the `op-sync-tester` via PR #17299. In addition to this merged work, they identified further testing needs by creating issues to address flakiness and add more tests (#17298, #17313), and also provided 3 code reviews. All of their code changes were concentrated in test files, reflecting a primary focus on test development and refactoring.

maurelian: Focused on repository maintenance and providing code review feedback this month. They merged a pull request to remove the Codecov configuration from CI in ethereum-optimism/superchain-registry (#1101). In addition to this change, they were highly engaged in collaboration, providing 11 code reviews for their peers. Their work primarily involved modifications to configuration files.

nonsense: Focused on improving CI and testing infrastructure, opening a significant pull request in ethereum-optimism/optimism (#17314) to add nightly sync tests. This work involved substantial changes, modifying 62 files with over 1100 new lines of code. In addition to this development effort, they actively supported the team by providing 8 code reviews. Their contributions were concentrated on test and configuration files, reflecting a focus on bugfixes and testing.

joshklop: Contributed directly to the codebase this month through 3 commits. These changes modified 42 files, adding over 1,200 lines of code. This activity was categorized as 'other work' and was not associated with any pull requests or issues.

serpixel: Focused on improving the acceptance test suite for `ethereum-optimism/optimism` this month. Their main contribution involved porting tests, which resulted in a significant refactor in PR #17300 that removed nearly 500 lines of code. To support this effort, they also opened and closed two related tracking issues in `ethereum-optimism/infra` (#444, #440). All of serpixel's code changes were concentrated on enhancing the project's test files.

ajsutton: This month, ajsutton focused on CI configuration, merging a pull request in `ethereum-optimism/optimism` (#17296) to adjust how a CI job runs. In addition to this change, they were an active collaborator, providing 3 code reviews and leaving 12 comments across various issues and pull requests. Their work this period centered on modifications to configuration files.

Wazabie: This month, Wazabie focused on upgrading several Sepolia environments in the `ethereum-optimism/superchain-ops` repository. They submitted three open pull requests (#1182, #1181, #1180) to advance the Mode, Metal, and Zora chains, which included changes across 37 files (+605/-26 lines). Wazabie also contributed one review approval, and their code changes were primarily focused on documentation and other operational updates.
mds1: Supported the team's progress this month by focusing on code review, providing 3 approvals on pull requests.
AmadiMichael: Focused on bugfix work this month, pushing two commits with over 100 lines of changes. They also supported the team by conducting two code reviews, which included one approval.
sebastianst: Focused on team collaboration this month by actively participating in code reviews. They provided feedback on 9 pull requests, which included 2 approvals and 1 request for changes.
agusduha: No activity this month.

stevennevins: Focused on a significant body of work this month, authoring 35 commits and modifying over 5,600 lines of code. While no pull requests were merged, they also contributed through collaboration by reviewing and approving two pull requests. Their code changes indicate a primary focus on bug fixes, which constituted 63% of their work, along with contributions to tests.
mbaxter: No activity this month.
wiz-inc-a178a98b5d: No activity this month.
Inphi: Contributed to the team's progress this month through code review, providing two approvals on pull requests.

wlawt: Focused on a significant implementation for `min-base-fee`, opening a large pull request in ethereum-optimism/optimism (#17315). This work involved 104 commits and substantial changes across 583 files (+18532/-12114 lines). The code changes indicate a primary focus on new development and bug fixes, with work split between core code and test files.
alcueca: No activity this month.

chuxinh: This month, chuxinh focused on expanding analytics capabilities by merging a single, substantial pull request in the `ethereum-optimism/op-analytics` repository. This contribution, PR #1740, added a new chain analysis output and involved a significant effort, reflected in its size of over 44,000 new lines of code. All of their activity was concentrated on delivering this impactful analytics feature.
almanax-ai: No activity this month.

ccerv1: Focused on the `ethereum-optimism/Retro-Funding` repository, where their primary contribution was adding the scaffolding for S8 rewards calculations in a significant effort (PR #74). They also resolved a bug to ensure monthly summary metrics were correctly included in the JSON output (PR #75). Based on their commits, their work was primarily categorized as bug fixes, with additional efforts in feature development, refactoring, and testing.

hexshire: Pushed 7 commits with significant code changes, modifying 37 files (+3368/-303 lines), though this work has not yet been submitted as a pull request. Their only other activity was leaving one comment on a pull request review.
mslipper: No activity this month.
Ethnical: No activity this month.

leopoldjoy: Focused on bugfix work this month, committing a substantial number of changes (+1447/-70 lines) across 18 files. They also contributed to collaborative efforts by providing comments on 3 pull requests.
zhwrd: No activity this month.

fainashalts: This month, fainashalts focused on supporting project development and identifying improvements. They actively participated in code review, providing 3 approvals and one comment on a pull request. Additionally, they opened an issue in `ethereum-optimism/ethereum-optimism.github.io` (#1122) to propose using the Superchain Registry for token chain data.
0xiamflux: No activity this month.

pauldowman: Focused on project planning and architectural design within the ethereum-optimism/optimism repository this month. They initiated several key workstreams by creating issues, most notably kicking off the design for the "Aggregate Dispute Game" (#17305). Their activity also included defining shipping checklists (#15827) and outlining testing requirements (#17303, #17302), indicating a strong emphasis on project coordination and strategy.
teddyknox: No activity this month.
janjakubnanista: No activity this month.

its-everdred: Focused on codebase simplification within the `ethereum-optimism/ecosystem` repository this month. Their sole merged pull request (#946) was a significant refactor that removed over 1,800 lines of code. This work primarily involved modifications to code and configuration files.
ericbrown99: Contributed to the team's progress this month through code review, providing 3 approvals on pull requests.
tynes: No activity this month.

zhiqiangxu focused on improving test reliability by opening a pull request in ethereum-optimism/optimism (#17312) to better handle errors for the HTTP handler. This work-in-progress represents a substantial effort, modifying 348 files with over 14,000 lines of code added. All of their code changes this month were concentrated entirely within test files.
blockchaindevsh: No activity this month.

jvmi7: This month, jvmi7 focused on planning and defining a major frontend initiative within the ethereum-optimism/ecosystem. Their primary impact was architecting the Optimism marketing site's React migration by creating the central tracking issue (#937) and breaking down the project into numerous foundational tasks, including monorepo setup, CI/CD, and Storybook configuration (#938-#941). They also identified and created several smaller, targeted UI improvements across various ecosystem sites, such as font updates and security enhancements, which have since been closed.

wood-jp: This month, wood-jp focused on addressing a bug within the `ethereum-optimism/optimism` repository. They identified an issue with p2p gossip parameter parsing in `op-node` (#17308) and submitted a corresponding fix in an open pull request (#17309). The proposed change included updates to both code and tests, totaling +108/-17 lines. This activity demonstrates a clear focus on bug fixing within the node's p2p gossip functionality.

oooLowNeoNooo: This month, oooLowNeoNooo focused on improving the MIPS fault-proof VM within the `ethereum-optimism/optimism` repository. Their contribution consisted of opening a pull request to add bounds checking and validation (#17295), which involved a targeted change to a single code file.

MozirDmitriy: Focused on improving test suite correctness this month by opening a pull request to address a bug in the acceptance tests for ethereum-optimism/optimism (#17301). This proposed fix for a storage-to-hash alignment issue involved a small change to a single test file.

hawkadrian: Focused on test-related fixes this month, opening a pull request in ethereum-optimism/optimism (#17311) to address an issue with interop activation. All of their code contributions were concentrated on improving test work.

pabloflixxo: This month, pabloflixxo's activity was focused on a contribution to the ethereum-optimism project, where they opened a pull request to add the FLIXX token for base (ethereum-optimism/ethereum-optimism.github.io#1195). This work involved modifications to configuration files.
